subject: Re: [junit] Why no errors in JUnit 4?
msgSnippet: Agreed, but Kevin is right - errors vs. failures gave a clear indication of the problem: errors tend to be in configuration, failures tend to be in code. --
messageBody:
Agreed, but Kevin is right - errors vs. failures gave a clear indication
of the problem: errors tend to be in configuration, failures tend to be
in code.

--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Cedric Beust wrote:
>>From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>
>
>>I thought it gave a good starting place for looking for the problem.
>>My thinking went along the lines of:
>>
>>"What's wrong?"
>>
>>-4 errors, 0 failures-
>>
>>"Oh, something I wasn't expecting. I'll look at
>>config/environment stuff first"
>>
>>or
>>
>>"What's wrong?"
>>
>>-0 errors, 4 failures-
>>
>>"What code changed?"
>
>
> It doesn't make much difference in practice, because in both cases, the
> first thing you will do is take a look at the test that failed...
>
